sen.j: 陽明文庫（ようめいぶんこ）は、京都市右京区宇多野上ノ谷町にある特殊図書館。
sen.e: Located in Utanokaminotani Cho of Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City, Yomei Bunko is a particular kind of library.
Located in Utanokaminotani Cho of Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City, Yomei Bunko is a particular kind of library.
Located in Utano Kaminotani-cho of Ukyo-ku Ward, Kyoto City, Yomei Bunko is a particular kind of library.

sen.j: 公家の名門で「摂家」の筆頭である近衛家伝来の古文書（こもんじょ）、典籍、記録、日記、書状、古美術品など約20万点に及ぶ史料を保管している。
sen.e: It stores about twenty thousand items of legacy historical materials of the Konoe family, which was an honorable Kuge (court nobles) family and the head of Sekke (the five regent houses), such as ancient writing, old books, records, diaries, letters, and antique artworks.

It stores about twenty thousand items of legacy historical materials of the Konoe family, which was an honorable Kuge (court nobles) family and the head of Sekke (the five regent houses), such as ancient writing, old books, records, diaries, letters, and antique artworks.

It stores about twenty thousand items of legacy historical materials of the Konoe family, which was an honorable Kuge (court nobles) family and the head of Sekke (the five regent houses), such as ancient writing, old books, records, diaries, letters, and antique artworks.

sen.j: 昭和13年（1938年）、当時の近衛家の当主で内閣総理大臣であった近衛文麿が京都市街地の北西、仁和寺の近くの現在地に設立した。
sen.e: In 1938, Fumimaro KONOE, the Prime Minister and the head of the Konoe family at that time, built it in this place close to Ninna-ji Temple in the northwest of Kyoto City urban district.
In 1938, Fumimaro KONOE, the Prime Minister and the head of the Konoe family at that time, built it in this place close to Ninna-ji Temple in the northwest of Kyoto City urban district.
In 1938, Fumimaro KONOE, the Prime Minister and the head of the Konoe family at that time, built it in this place close to Ninna-ji Temple in the northwest of Kyoto City urban district.

sen.j: 近衛家の遠祖にあたる藤原道長（966 - 1028）の自筆日記『御堂関白記』から、20世紀の近衛文麿の関係資料まで、1,000年以上にわたる歴史資料を収蔵し、研究者に閲覧の便を図るとともに、影印本の刊行などの事業を行っている。
sen.e: It stores historical materials over a thousand years from "Mido Kanpakuki Diary" by FUJIWARA no Michinaga (966 - 1028) in his own handwriting, an ancestor of the Konoe family, to the documents related to Fumimaro KONOE in the twentieth century, and it not only lets researchers read them but publishes facsimile editions of them.

It stores historical materials that are over a thousand years old from the "Mido Kanpakuki Diary" by FUJIWARA no Michinaga (966 - 1028) in his own handwriting, an ancestor of the Konoe family, to the documents related to Fumimaro KONOE in the twentieth century, and it not only lets researchers read them but publishes facsimile editions of them.

It stores historical materials that are over a thousand years old from the "Mido Kanpakuki," diary by FUJIWARA no Michinaga (966 - 1028) in his own handwriting, an ancestor of the Konoe family, to the documents related to Fumimaro KONOE in the twentieth century, and it not only lets researchers read them but also publishes facsimile editions of them.

sen.j: これに匹敵するものに九条流摂関家の嫡流一条家の「桃華堂文庫」がある。
sen.e: A comparable library to this is 'Tokado Bunko Library' of the Ichijo family which is the direct line of descent of the Kujoryu Sekke (a descendent line of three Sekke families: the Ichijo, the Kujo, and Nijo).

A comparable library to this is the 'Tokado Bunko Library' of the Ichijo family which is the direct line of descent of the Kujoryu Sekke (a descendent line of three Sekke families: the Ichijo, the Kujo, and Nijo).
A comparable library to this is the 'Tokado Bunko Library' of the Ichijo family which is the direct line of descent of Sekkan-ke (the families which produced regents) of Kujo group.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

tit.e: Yomei Bunko and the Konoe family
Yomei Bunko and the Konoe family
Yomei Bunko and the Konoe family

sen.j: 近衛家は藤原北家の流れを汲む家である。
sen.e: The Konoe family is the descendant of the Northern House of Fujiwara clan.
The Konoe family is a descendant of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan.
The Konoe family is a descendant of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan.

sen.j: 藤原氏は、12世紀に摂政、関白、太政大臣を務めた藤原忠通（1097年 - 1164年）の後、その長男・近衛基実（1143年 - 1166年）を祖とする近衛家と三男・九条兼実（1149年 – 1207年）を祖とする九条家の2家に分かれ、その後近衛家からは鷹司家が、九条家からは二条家、一条家が分かれた。
sen.e: After FUJIWARA no Tadamichi (1097 - 1164) who served as Sessho (regent), Kanpaku (chief advisor of the Emperor), and Dajodaijin (chancellor) in the twelfth century, the Fujiwara clan split into two branch families, the Konoe family whose founder was Tadamichi's first son Motozane KONOE (1143 - 1166), and the Kujo Family whose founder was Tadamichi's third son Kanezane KUJO (1149 - 1207), and later, the Takatsukasa family split out from the Konoe family, and the Nijo family and the Ichijo family from the Kujo family.

After FUJIWARA no Tadamichi (1097 - 1164) who served as Sessho (regent), Kanpaku (chief advisor of the Emperor), and Dajodaijin (chancellor) in the twelfth century, the Fujiwara clan split into two branch families, the Konoe family whose founder was Tadamichi's first son Motozane KONOE (1143 - 1166), and the Kujo Family whose founder was Tadamichi's third son Kanezane KUJO (1149 - 1207), and later, the Takatsukasa family split off from the Konoe family, and the Nijo family and the Ichijo family broke off from the Kujo family.

After FUJIWARA no Tadamichi (1097 - 1164) who served as Sessho (regent), Kanpaku (chief advisor of the Emperor), and Dajodaijin (chancellor) in the twelfth century, the Fujiwara clan split into two branch families, the Konoe family whose founder was Tadamichi's first son Motozane KONOE (1143 - 1166), and the Kujo Family whose founder was Tadamichi's third son Kanezane KUJO (1149 - 1207), and later, the Takatsukasa family split off from the Konoe family, and the Nijo family and the Ichijo family broke off from the Kujo family.

sen.j: 後に近衛、鷹司、九条、二条、一条の5家を「五摂家」と呼ぶようになった。
sen.e: Later, the five families, the Takatsukasa family, the Kujo family, the Nijo family, and the Ichijo family, were called 'Go Sekke' (five branches of the Fujiwara family).
Later, the five families, the Takatsukasa family, the Kujo family, the Nijo family, and the Ichijo family, were called 'Go Sekke' (five branches of the Fujiwara family).
Later, the five families, the Konoe, the Takatsukasa, the Kujo, the Nijo, and the Ichijo, were called 'Go Sekke' (five branches of the Fujiwara family).

sen.j: 近衛家の祖である近衛基実は藤原忠通が40歳を過ぎてから生まれた長男で、若くして氏長者となり、関白に任じられたが、24歳の若さで他界した。
sen.e: Motozane KONOE, the first son of Tadamichi FUJIWARA and the founder of the Konoe family, was born when his father was over forty years old, and succeeded Uji Choja (the chief of the clan) and Kanpaku, but died at the age of twenty-four.

Motozane KONOE, the first son of Tadamichi FUJIWARA and the founder of the Konoe family, was born when his father was over forty years old, and succeeded Uji Choja (the chief of the clan) and Kanpaku, but died at the age of twenty-four.

Motozane KONOE, the first son of FUJIWARA no Tadamichi and the founder of the Konoe family, was born when his father FUJIWARA no Tadamichi was over forty years old, and succeeded Uji Choja (the chief of the clan) and Kanpaku, but died at the age of twenty-four.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせました。

sen.j: 近衛家の歴代当主は、藤原道長の日記『御堂関白記』をはじめ、先祖の日記や朝廷の儀式関係などの重要な文書記録を大切に伝えてきた。
sen.e: Successive heads of the Konoe family have inherited and taken good care of important documents and records, such as diaries of ancestors, and records of ceremonies of the Imperial Court, including "Mido Kanpakuki Diary" by FUJIWARA no Michinaga.

Successive heads of the Konoe family have inherited and taken good care of the important documents and records, such as diaries of ancestors, and records of ceremonies of the Imperial Court, including "Mido Kanpakuki Diary" by FUJIWARA no Michinaga.

Successive heads of the Konoe family have inherited and taken good care of the important documents and records, such as diaries of ancestors, and records of ceremonies of the Imperial Court, including "Mido Kanpakuki," diary of FUJIWARA no Michinaga.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせました。

sen.j: 近衛家が、応仁の乱や戦国時代の動乱を経て、家伝の古文書類を千年以上にわたり伝えてきたことは特記に値する。
sen.e: It is worthy of special attention that the Konoe family has handed down its family treasure of ancient documents over a thousand years through Onin-no-Ran Battle (a civil war from 1467 to 1477 during the Muromachi period) and the Sengoku period (period of warring states).

It is worthy of special attention to note that the Konoe family has handed down its family treasure of ancient documents for over a thousand years through Onin-no-Ran Battle (a civil war from 1467 to 1477 during the Muromachi period) and the Sengoku period (period of warring states).

It is worthy of special attention to note that the Konoe family has handed down its family treasure of ancient documents for over a thousand years through the Onin War (a civil war from 1467 to 1477 during the Muromachi period) and the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 戦国時代の動乱期に関白・太政大臣を務めた13代当主近衛政家（1445年 – 1505年）は、応仁・文明の乱に際し、家伝の古文書（唐櫃50合の分量があったという）を京都の北郊の岩倉に疎開させた。
sen.e: The thirteenth head of the Konoe family, Masaie KONOE (1445 - 1505) who served as Kanpaku, and Dajodaijin during the turbulent era of the Sengoku period, evacuated the family treasure of ancient documents (they are said to have measured fifty Karabitsu, a container of 50 cm x 33 cm x 40 cm, in volume) to Iwakura in the north of Kyoto.

The thirteenth head of the Konoe family, Masaie KONOE (1445 - 1505) who served as Kanpaku, and Dajodaijin during the turbulent era of the Sengoku period, evacuated the family treasure of ancient documents (they are said to have measured fifty Karabitsu, a container of 50 cm x 33 cm x 40 cm, in volume) to Iwakura in the north of Kyoto.

The thirteenth head of the Konoe family, Masaie KONOE (1445 - 1505) who served as Kanpaku, and Dajodaijin during the turbulent era of the Sengoku Period, evacuated the family treasure of ancient documents (they are said to have measured fifty Karabitsu, a container of 50 cm x 33 cm x 40 cm, in volume) to Iwakura in the north of Kyoto.

sen.j: 応仁の乱によって近衛家の邸宅は焼失したが、古文書類は難を逃れた。
sen.e: Although the Konoe family's house was destroyed by fire during Onin-no-Ran Battle, the ancient documents have survived the turmoil.
Although the Konoe family's house was destroyed by fire during Onin-no-Ran Battle, the ancient documents have survived the turmoil.
Although the Konoe family's house was destroyed by fire during the Onin War, the ancient documents have survived the turmoil.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 16代当主近衛前久（さきひさ、号は応山、1536年 – 1612年）は、室町幕府の崩壊、本能寺の変、徳川幕府成立という激動の時代に関白を務め、関白の職にありながら、上杉謙信と同盟を結んで越後に赴くなど数奇な生涯を送った人物であるが、彼も家伝文書の保存には意を払い、文書を比叡山の麓の坂本に疎開させたという。
sen.e: The sixteenth head of the Konoe family, Sakihisa KONOE (the pseudonym Ozan, 1536 - 1612), who served as Kanpaku over the periods of the demise of Muromachi Shogunate, Honnoji Incident (a battle in which Nobunaga was killed), and the foundation of Tokugawa Shougnate, led a turbulent life serving as Kanpaku to move to Echigo (the Niigata region) to make an alliance with Kenshin UESUGI, also took a good care of the family treasure of documents to evacuate them to Sakamoto at the foot of Hiei-zan Mountain.

The sixteenth head of the Konoe family, Sakihisa KONOE (the pseudonym Ozan, 1536 - 1612), who served as Kanpaku over the periods of the demise of Muromachi Shogunate, Honnoji Incident (a battle in which Nobunaga was killed), and the foundation of Tokugawa Shougnate, led a turbulent life serving as Kanpaku to move to Echigo (the Niigata region) to make an alliance with Kenshin UESUGI, also took a good care of the family treasure of documents and evacuated them to Sakamoto at the foot of Hiei-zan Mountain.

The sixteenth head of the Konoe family, Sakihisa KONOE (the pseudonym Ozan, 1536 - 1612), who served as Kanpaku over the periods of the demise of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), Honnoji Incident (a battle in which Nobunaga was killed), and the foundation of Tokugawa Shogunate, led a turbulent life serving as Kanpaku to move to Echigo (the Niigata region) to make an alliance with Kenshin UESUGI, also took a good care of the family treasure of documents and evacuated them to Sakamoto at the foot of Mt. Hiei.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 近世の近衛家当主には、詩書画などの諸芸に通じた教養人・風流人が多く、彼らによって伝世の古文書が整理され、新たな書物が収集された。
sen.e: Many of the successive Konoe family heads in the end of the fifteenth century and in the Edo period, who were learned and had refined taste with poetry, calligraphy, and paintings, sorted out the handed down ancient documents, and added book collections as well.

Many of the successive Konoe family heads at the end of the fifteenth century and during the Edo period, who were educated and had a refined taste of poetry, calligraphy, and painting, sorted out the handed down ancient documents, and added book collections as well.

Many of the successive Konoe family heads in the early-modern times, who were educated and had a refined taste of poetry, calligraphy, and painting, sorted out the handed down ancient documents, and added book collections as well.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 17代当主の近衛信尹（のぶただ、1565年 - 1614年) は三藐院（さんみゃくいん）と号し、「寛永の三筆」の一人に数えられる能書家で教養人であった。
sen.e: The seventeenth head of the Konoe family, Nobutada KONOE (1565 - 1614), the pseudonym Sanmyakuin, was a learned man and a calligrapher, one of the so-called 'Kanei no Sanpitsu' or the Three Prominent Brushes of the Kanei period.

The seventeenth head of the Konoe family, Nobutada KONOE (1565 - 1614), the pseudonym Sanmyakuin, was an educated man and a calligrapher, one of the so-called 'Kanei no Sanpitsu' or the Three Prominent Brushes of the Kanei period.

The seventeenth head of the Konoe family, Nobutada KONOE (1565 - 1614), the pseudonym Sanmyakuin, was an educated man and a calligrapher, one of the so-called 'Kanei no Sanpitsu' or the Three Prominent Brushes of the Kanei period.

sen.j: 信尹には継嗣がなかったため、後陽成天皇の第4皇子であり、信尹には甥にあたる近衛信尋（のぶひろ、号応山、1599年 - 1649年）を養子に迎えた。
sen.e: Because Nobutada had no child as a successor, he adopted Nobuhiro KONOE (the pseudonym Ozan, 1599 - 1649) who was his nephew and the fourth prince of Emperor Goyozei.
Because Nobutada had no child as a successor, he adopted Nobuhiro KONOE (the pseudonym Ozan, 1599 - 1649) who was his nephew and the fourth prince of Emperor Goyozei.
Because Nobutada had no child as a successor, he adopted Nobuhiro KONOE (the pseudonym Ozan, 1599 - 1649) who was his nephew and the fourth prince of Emperor Goyozei.

sen.j: 信尋も書道、茶道、連歌などの芸道に通じた教養人であった。
sen.e: Nomuhiro was also a learned man who was well versed in various arts, such as calligraphy, tea ceremony, and renga (a poetic form, poetic dialogue).
Nomuhiro was also an educated man who was well versed in various arts, such as calligraphy, tea ceremony, and renga (a poetic form, poetic dialogue).
Nomuhiro was also an educated man who was well versed in various arts, such as calligraphy, tea ceremony, and renga (a poetic form, poetic dialogue).

sen.j: 江戸時代中期の人物である21代当主近衛家熙（いえひろ、号予楽院、1667年 - 1736年）も詩書画に優れた教養人であった。
sen.e: The twenty-first head of the Konoe family, Iehiro KONOE (the pseudonym Yorakuin, 1667 - 1736) in the middle of the Edo period was also a learned man well versed in poetry, calligraphy, and paintings.

The twenty-first head of the Konoe family, Iehiro KONOE (the pseudonym Yorakuin, 1667 - 1736) during the middle of the Edo period was also an educated man well versed in poetry, calligraphy, and painting.

The twenty-first head of the Konoe family, Iehiro KONOE (the pseudonym Yorakuin, 1667 - 1736) during the middle of the Edo period was also an educated man well versed in poetry, calligraphy, and painting.

sen.j: これら歴代の近衛家当主によって守られてきた古文書類は、近代に入って明治33年（1900年）から数度に分けて京都大学附属図書館に寄託された。
sen.e: These ancient documents that had been cherished by the successive heads of the Konoe family were donated in a few batches to Kyoto University Library following 1900 in the modern era.
These ancient documents that had been cherished by the successive heads of the Konoe family were donated in a few batches to Kyoto University Library following 1900 in the modern era.
These ancient documents that had been cherished by the successive heads of the Konoe family were donated in a few batches to Kyoto University Library following 1900 in the modern era.

sen.j: その後、昭和期の当主であり、第二次大戦開戦に至る激動の時代に総理大臣を務めた近衛文麿は昭和13年（1938年）に財団法人陽明文庫を設立し、家蔵の資料の永久保存を図ることとした。
sen.e: Later, Fumimaro KONOE, who was the family head in the Showa period and served as the Prime Minister in the turbulent era up to the outbreak of the Second World War, decided to establish the Yomei Bunko Foundation in 1938 to permanently store the family treasure of historical materials.

Later, Fumimaro KONOE, who was the family head during the Showa period and served as the Prime Minister in the turbulent era up to the outbreak of the Second World War, decided to establish the Yomei Bunko Foundation in 1938 to permanently store the family treasure of historical materials.

Later, Fumimaro KONOE, who was the family head during the Showa period and served as the Prime Minister in the turbulent era up to the outbreak of the Second World War, decided to establish the Yomei Bunko Foundation in 1938 to permanently store the family treasure of historical materials.

sen.j: 「陽明」の名は、近衛家の屋敷が大内裏の14門の1つである近衛門内にあったことにちなむものである。
sen.e: The name 'Yomei' came from the fact that the house of the Konoe family used to be on the street that began at Yomeimon Gate which was one of the fourteen gates of Daidairi Palace.
sen.cmt: 近衛門内ではなく，陽明門の通りにあったというのが正しいようですので，原文を修正して訳しました．参考(http://tohjurou.blog55.fc2.com/blog-entry-731.html) また，現在のWikipediaも，そのように記述しています．
sen.e: The name 'Yomei' came from the fact that the house of the Konoe family used to be on the street that began at Yomeimon Gate which was one of the fourteen gates of Daidairi Palace.
The name 'Yomei' came from the fact that the house of the Konoe family used to be on the street that began at Yomeimon Gate which was one of the fourteen gates of Daidairi Palace.

sen.j: 文庫は洛西の仁和寺の近くに位置する。
sen.e: Yomei Bunko Library is close to Ninna-ji Temple in the Rakusei area (the western part of Kyoto).
The Yomei Bunko Library is close to Ninna-ji Temple in the Rakusei area (the western part of Kyoto).
The Yomei Bunko Library is close to Ninna-ji Temple in the Rakusei area (the western part of Kyoto).

sen.j: 約10,000㎡の敷地内には、文庫設立以来の建物である書庫2棟、閲覧事務所のほか、昭和19年（1944年）に建てられた数寄屋造の虎山荘が建つ。
sen.e: In its compound of about 10,000 m2, there stand two storerooms of books which were built when this library was founded, its access office, and Kozanso villa of Sukiya-zukuri style built in 1944.
In its compound of about 10,000 m2, there stand two storerooms of books that were built when this library was founded, its access office, and Kozanso villa of Sukiya-zukuri style was built in 1944.

In its compound of about 10,000 square meters, there stand two storerooms of books that were built when this library was founded, its access office, and Kozanso villa of Sukiya-zukuri style (built in the style of a tea-ceremony house) was built in 1944.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: これらは昭和期の貴重な建造物として、国の登録有形文化財に登録されている。
sen.e: These are valued architecture in the Showa period and are designated as National Registered Cultural Properties.
These are valued architecture from the Showa period and are designated as National Registered Cultural Properties.
These are valued architecture from the Showa period and are designated as National Registered Cultural Properties.

sen.j: 蔵書は、藤原道長自筆の日記『御堂関白記』をはじめとする公卿の日記類がまとまって収蔵されており、いずれも一級の歴史資料である。
sen.e: Stored at the same place are "Mido Kanpakuki Diary" written by FUJIWARA no Michinaga's own hand and other court noble's diaries, which are all first grade historical materials.
Stored at the same place are the "Mido Kanpakuki Diary" written by FUJIWARA no Michinaga's own hand and other court noble's diaries, that are all first grade historical materials.
Stored at the same place are the "Mido Kanpakuki," diary written by FUJIWARA no Michinaga himself, and other court noble's diaries, that are all first grade historical materials.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: また、天皇や歴史上の著名人の自筆書状、宮廷儀式関係、物語や和歌集の古写本なども多数収蔵し、歴史資料としてのみならず、書道史上の遺品としても貴重なものが多い。
sen.e: It also stores many autograph letters by Emperors and historical prominent figures, documents related to the ceremonies in the Imperial Court, and a number of items of ancient copies of old tales and anthologies of Waka poems, many of which are not only valued as historical materials but also artifacts of the history of calligraphy.

It also stores many autograph letters by Emperors and historical prominent figures, documents related to the ceremonies in the Imperial Court, and a number of items of ancient copies of old tales and anthologies of Waka poems, many of which are not only valued as historical materials but also artifacts of the history of calligraphy.

It also stores many autograph letters by emperors and historical prominent figures, documents related to the ceremonies in the Imperial Court, and a number of items of ancient copies of old tales and anthologies of Waka poems, many of which are not only valued as historical materials but also artifacts of the history of calligraphy.

sen.j: 第二次大戦後、旧公家・大名家伝来の文化財の多くが散佚した中にあって、近衛家の所蔵品は、早くから財団化されていたため、まとまって伝来している点も貴重である。
sen.e: Although many cultural properties inherited by former court nobles and daimyo (domain lords) families were lost at the end of the Second World War, the Konoe family's collections are very important because they have been protected at one place by the foundation that was established early.

Although many cultural properties inherited by former court nobles and daimyo (domain lords) families were lost at the end of the Second World War, the Konoe family's collections are very important because they have been protected at one place by the foundation that was established early.

Although many cultural properties inherited by former court nobles and daimyo (domain lords) families were lost at the end of the Second World War, the Konoe family's collections are very important because they have been protected at one place by the foundation that was established early.

sen.j: 書庫の階上に陳列室があるが、原則として一般公開はしておらず、閲覧には紹介状が必要である。
sen.e: It has a display room above the storeroom, but it is not open to the public requiring a letter of introduction to read the materials.
It has a display room above the storeroom, but it is not open to the public and requires a letter of introduction to read the materials.
It has a display room above the storeroom, but it is not open to the public and requires a letter of introduction to read the materials.

sen.j: なお、主要な貴重書の影印は『陽明叢書』として逐次刊行されている。
sen.e: It is publishing facsimile editions of major valued books as "Yomei Sosho."
It is publishing facsimile editions of major valued books as "Yomei Sosho."
It is publishing with photograph of major valued books as "Yomei Sosho" (Yomei Collection of Books).
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: ちなみに一条家の「桃華堂文庫」は写本が存在するといわれるが、現在は不明である。
sen.e: Incidentally, although its copy is said to exist somewhere, 'Tokado Bunko Library' of the Ichijo family is lost now.
Incidentally, although its copy is said to exist somewhere, the 'Tokado Bunko Library' of the Ichijo family is now lost.
Incidentally, although its copy is said to exist somewhere, the 'Tokado Bunko Library' of the Ichijo family is now lost.

sen.j: 御堂関白記 26巻（自筆本14巻、写本12巻）附御堂御記抄、御堂御暦記目録 - 藤原道長の日記で、自筆本は33歳の長徳4年（998年）から55歳の寛仁5年（1021年）にわたり、断続的に14巻が残っている。
sen.e: Mido Kanpakuki Diary, 26 volumes (14 volumes of autograph and 12 volumes of transcription), including Midogyokisho Excerpts, Catalogue of Mido Goryakuki; diaries of FUJIWARA no Michinaga; its 14 volumes in his own handwriting cover the years from 998 (his age of thirty-three) to 1021 (his age of fifty-five) with interruptions.

Mido Kanpakuki Diary, 26 volumes (14 volumes of autograph and 12 volumes of transcription), including Midogyokisho Excerpts, Catalogue of Mido Goryakuki; diaries of FUJIWARA no Michinaga; its 14 volumes in his own handwriting cover the years from 998 (his age of thirty-three) to 1021 (his age of fifty-five) with interruptions.

26 volumes Mido Kanpakuki (14 volumes of autograph and 12 volumes of transcription), attached Midogyokisho Excerpts, Catalogue of Mido Goryakuki: Diaries of FUJIWARA no Michinaga, the remaining 14 volumes in his own handwriting cover from 998 (his age of thirty-three) to 1021 (his age of fifty-five) with interruptions.

sen.j: 展示 観覧は春・秋各3か月間のみ（事前に予約のあった団体に限る）。
sen.e: It accepts visitors to see inside and hold exhibitions only for three months in spring and autumn each (only for groups that make reservations in advance).

Open hours: 10:00 to 16:00; closed: Sundays and National Holidays

sen.j: 住所 京都市右京区宇多野上ノ谷町1-2
sen.e: Location: 1-2 Utanokaminotani Cho, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City
Location: 1-2 Utanokaminotani Cho, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City

sen.j: アクセス 京都駅より京都市営バス・JRバス栂尾方面行き「福王子」下車徒歩数分
sen.e: Access: from Kyoto Station, take Kyoto City Bus or JR Bus for Toganoo, get off at 'Fukuoji' bus stop, and it is a few minutes on foot to the library.
Access: from Kyoto Station, take Kyoto City Bus or JR Bus for Toganoo, get off at 'Fukuoji' bus stop, and it is a few minutes on foot to the library.
